content:
This stream was set up for Backdrop LIVE and other events. I'm going to take it over for administrative stuff regarding Open Source Day and a place for anyone interested to ask questions.

We will not be inviting participants here. But anyone in our regular Zulip channels can join.

I will continue to post requests for code reviews to the main stream. This is for more administrative stuff.

I updated the Welcome Message on our blog to include a link to coding standards.

My advice to participants will be that they should do their best with coding standards, but not stress about them. We would rather that they file a Pull Request and get feedback than fail to file a Pull Request because they are worried about coding standards.
Feedback on that strategy is welcome
https://backdropcms.org/ghc-osd2020-getting-started

This was in the packet of information for project representatives

"Have a minimum of 35 beginner-friendly bugs or features ready before OSD (Oct 1st, 2020) to distribute to participants. Include different types if you can: backend, frontend, triage, documentation, CSS, UI, or artwork are all valid."
Please, post ideas here for tasks that are not code specific, just in case we have folks that are interested in them.
Documentation tasks, testing tasks, etc.
Re. coding standards: as long as they're aware we have some, and where to find them, then they won't be surprised when someone asks for small changes like whitespace, etc.
Re. non-coding issues, they can contribute to documentation or design related issues maybe.

Re. coding standards: as long as they're aware we have some, and where to find them, then they won't be surprised when someone asks for small changes like whitespace, etc.

Yes, I agree that it is important for them to know about them. We'll also be chatting with participants in Slack on Thursday and can reinforce that message.

Re. non-coding issues, they can contribute to documentation or design related issues maybe.

Yes, I'm looking for specific ideas or even issue numbers. There might be some good stuff in the BackdropCMS.org issue queue. I will look there later, but i appreciate any tips.

Here are the project guidelines and FAQ for anyone interested.

OSD-2020-Project-Guidelines-FAQ.pdf
@jenlampton and/or @klonos - We should have a short Zoom call yet today to talk about tomorrow and any last minute prep.
I am generally available the rest of the day - other than dinner break.
Sure, I am generally available after I finish this update...
@jenlampton or @klonos - Checking in
@StPaulTim hai :) It's been a day
I know the feeling
@jenlampton will you be around for a short while. I'm in the middle of something
I seem to be in and out..
@jenlampton - If you are around in 20 minutes, it would be a good time to check in.
9 Central or 7 Pacific
I'm in my zoom room if anyone wants to drop in and talk about OSD tomorrow.
@StPaulTim I'm around now :wave:
...damn it. Urgent tickets came through. GTG :disappointed:

https://us02web.zoom.us/j/81170800567?pwd=UkphR0cwWkJTSSsrWjhnNVBVNjNvZz09

Join our Cloud HD Video Meeting
Zoom is the leader in modern enterprise video communications, with an easy, reliable cloud platform for video and audio conferencing, chat, and webinars across mobile, desktop, and room systems. Zoom Rooms is the original software-based conference room solution used around the world in board, conference, huddle, and training rooms, as well as executive offices and classrooms. Founded in 2011, Zoom helps businesses and organizations bring their teams together in a frictionless environment to get more done. Zoom is a publicly traded company headquartered in San Jose, CA.
Just helped someone who posted a question in an old, closed issue. Not sure if they're part of OSD or not...
(with a name like Michael I'm guessing not...)
Probably not, but you never know. I've encouraged OSD participants to mention OSD in their comments.
That looks like Michael-IDA, who has been around for a while. Posts quite a bit in the forum, I think.
Just realized that I'm still in Zoom room.
Going to close up shop.
What time does the event start? ...I've got the impression that the main event is US-only, so I'll need to convert that to my timezone.
The entire event starts at 9:30am (Pacific Time) and runs until 6:00pm (Pacific). There is a wrap up at 5:30.
It looks like the contribution track does not start until 10:00 (Pacific). There is some intro session from 9:30-10:00.

My key thoughts about tomorrow (my opinions):

1) Don't overwhelm folks with too much information all at once. Just get them what they need to get started and then keep providing additional help throughout the day.
2) In Drupal sprints, we've learned the importance of getting people to post a comment in the issue queue. This is a big step and allows others in the community to offer advice and help.
3) At in-person beginner sprints, I spend a lot of time going around and asking people how they are doing and if they need help. We need to figure out the best way to do that in this virtual environment. We may need to keep a list and be sure that we reach out to every active participant a couple of times during the day.

@klonos and @jenlampton - If you haven't read your emails (not accusing anyone of anything), we will have a Zoom room provided for us tomorrow and we are expected there at about 9:15 Pacific time (as I understand it). It's unclear to me if we get participants at 9:30 or 10:00.
OK, I didn't get everything done that I hoped I would. But, I'm feeling fairly good about tomorrow. I have a few client things to do, before I get some sleep. We start in 9 hours.

OK, thanks @StPaulTim ++ ...I guess that it'd be 7:30pm my time ...that's perfectly fine; I'll make sure that I have gotten enough rest, because 6hrs into the event I need to start a full work day, and then I have a 4-5hr drive to Athens after that (I'll most likely be unavailable throughout the weekend, as my missus is getting LASIK done). ...seriously considering calling in sick too :sweat_smile:
stpaultim :-) (Karma: 28)
@StPaulTim I added the zoom link to the google calendar event for OSD tomorrow -- I will be there around 9am.

One of the reasons it's so hard to get people to post a comment on Drupal issues is that there are 500 fields that people don't know how to answer. I don't expect we'll have the same kind of form-overload-anxiety on GitHub, but I suppose we'll find out tomorrow! :)

I'm really looking forward to this, but I do have two un-backdrop related urgent issues that might pop up, one is a meeting with a laywer for my NP and another is a personal call that's super important. I do expect the rest of my day to be devoted to OSD though, so hopefully those two calls won't be too distracting...
sorry for my radio silence so far this week, it's been a week.
I hope that everything is ok with you. It will be good.

StPaulTim said:

3) At in-person beginner sprints, I spend a lot of time going around and asking people how they are doing and if they need help. We need to figure out the best way to do that in this virtual environment. We may need to keep a list and be sure that we reach out to every active participant a couple of times during the day.

You could also use the Slack channel to do that, assuming all or most of the participants will be there, but it would likely be more like a general announcement from a podium to the entire room.
It's starting :)
I'm switching over to slack...
How's it all going?
Well, we wrapped up about 30 minutes ago
I think it went pretty good. I would say that we had about 10-15 participants in total. Some didn't stay long. About 4-5 stuck around for most of the day.
A couple of them seemed pretty engaged and enjoying the process.

One participant spent quite a while trying to install Backdrop CMS on their local Windows machine. She had difficulties with Lando and moved on to XAMP. Also had some trouble with XAMP, but they were able to figure it out and get Backdrop running.

@jenlampton and I had the opportunity to watch this participant navigate the installation process. It was interesting and may lead to a few new issues in the issue queue.
Good to hear :smile:
I think this was definitely worth doing. I wish he had a few more participants. Maybe next time.
